recommended_movies: The Girl with All the Gifts (2016)

simulated_ratings.title: The Thing (1982)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Paranoia, isolation, and a shape-shifting nightmare—this is exactly my kind of terror.

simulated_ratings.title: The Fly (1986)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Grotesque and tragic body-horror that hit hard and stuck with me.

simulated_ratings.title: Alien (1979)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Perfect slow-burn space dread that squeezed me from start to finish.

simulated_ratings.title: Aliens (1986)
simulated_ratings.feeling: White-knuckle sci-fi carnage with real stakes and momentum.

simulated_ratings.title: 28 Days Later (2002)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Bleak, propulsive survival that burrowed under my skin.

simulated_ratings.title: [REC] (2007)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Claustrophobic and escalating in all the right ways.

simulated_ratings.title: The Descent (2005)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Suffocating tension and vicious turns that had me clenched.

simulated_ratings.title: The Wailing (2016)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Uneasy and haunting, though the deliberate pace tested me.

simulated_ratings.title: Let the Right One In (2008)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Quietly unsettling and tender, but a bit too hushed for me.

simulated_ratings.title: It Follows (2014)
simulated_ratings.feeling: This felt mismatched and never clicked with me.

simulated_ratings.title: The Witch (2015)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Slick fantasy action that left me cold.

simulated_ratings.title: The Shining (1980)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Oppressive atmosphere and mounting madness that I loved sinking into.

simulated_ratings.title: The Mist (2007)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Nerve-shredding siege and cosmic dread that hit a nasty sweet spot.

simulated_ratings.title: A Quiet Place (2018)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Smart, tense, and heartfelt with a killer high-concept hook.

simulated_ratings.title: Children of Men (2006)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Visceral, grounded future-shock that felt terrifyingly real.

simulated_ratings.title: Arrival (2016)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Thoughtful and somber, engaging my head more than my gut.

simulated_ratings.title: Annihilation (2018)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Eerie, mind-bending sci-fi horror that lingered like a bruise.

simulated_ratings.title: Predator (1987)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Brutal jungle cat-and-mouse that still rips.

simulated_ratings.title: 30 Days of Night (2007)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A savage, wintry siege that scratched my survival-horror itch.

simulated_ratings.title: The Howling (1981)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Solid werewolf vibes I respect more than I loved.

simulated_ratings.title: The Texas Chain Saw Massacre (1974)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Grimy, relentless nightmare energy that still got to me.

simulated_ratings.title: The Strangers (2008)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Simple, merciless home invasion that rattled me.

simulated_ratings.title: Bone Tomahawk (2015)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Slow burn frontier dread that erupts into brutal horror.

simulated_ratings.title: Hush (2016)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Taut and clever with sharp, sensory-driven suspense.

simulated_ratings.title: The Host (2006)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Family-driven monster chaos with real stakes and momentum.

simulated_ratings.title: Dawn of the Dead (2004)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Punchy, kinetic zombie mayhem I had a blast with.

simulated_ratings.title: The Girl with All the Gifts (2016)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Fresh ideas and mood, even if it wobbles at times.

simulated_ratings.title: The Loved Ones (2009)
simulated_ratings.feeling: This polished rom-com vibe isn’t in my wheelhouse at all.

simulated_ratings.title: The Blob (1988)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Gooey practical mayhem and small-town siege vibes hit my creature-feature sweet spot.

simulated_ratings.title: Prince of Darkness (1987)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Science-meets-occult siege with creeping cosmic dread that I loved sinking into.

simulated_ratings.title: Event Horizon (1997)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Grim, space-bound nightmare corridors and mounting dread kept me clenched.

simulated_ratings.title: Pitch Black (2000)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Lean survival with a killer light-vs-dark hook and sharp creature tension.

simulated_ratings.title: 28 Weeks Later (2007)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A brutal, breathless follow-up that keeps the rage-fueled survival pressure on.

simulated_ratings.title: The Crazies (2010)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Small-town outbreak chaos and siege energy scratched my survival-horror itch.

simulated_ratings.title: Stake Land (2010)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Bleak, road-warrior vampire survival that worked more on mood than momentum for me.

simulated_ratings.title: The Borderlands (2013)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Vague, slow-burn supernatural threads left me more cool than rattled.

simulated_ratings.title: As Above, So Below (2014)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Claustrophobic descent and escalating occult madness pressed all my buttons.

simulated_ratings.title: The Taking of Deborah Logan (2014)
simulated_ratings.feeling: From intimate decay to unnerving possession, it got under my skin enough.

simulated_ratings.title: The Void (2016)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Bleak hospital siege with gnarly transformations and culty cosmic terror I dig.

simulated_ratings.title: 10 Cloverfield Lane (2016)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Paranoid bunker mind games with real stakes had me on edge start to finish.

simulated_ratings.title: Life (2017)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Tense, grim space survival and a smart predator vibe I can’t resist.

simulated_ratings.title: The Ritual (2017)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Forest grief and stalking menace worked, even if the pace wobbles.

simulated_ratings.title: Overlord (2018)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Grimy wartime carnage meets monster mayhem in a punchy, nasty package.

simulated_ratings.title: Upgrade (2018)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Visceral, propulsive techno-revenge with bone-crunching payoff.

simulated_ratings.title: The Platform (2019)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A ruthless high-concept pressure cooker that gnawed at me.

simulated_ratings.title: The Invisible Man (2020)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Gaslighted tech-terror with taut, relentless tension that landed.

simulated_ratings.title: Possessor (2020)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Cold-blooded identity erosion and flesh-and-mind horror that lingered like a bruise.

simulated_ratings.title: Underwater (2020)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Relentless deep-sea sprint with suffocating pressure and creature dread.

simulated_ratings.title: The Empty Man (2020)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Moody occult mystery with unsettling ideas that outpaced its pulse.

simulated_ratings.title: A Quiet Place Part II (2021)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Tense, kinetic continuation that widens the world without losing the grip.

simulated_ratings.title: Barbarian (2022)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Twisty, nasty descent that blindsides and then bludgeons.

simulated_ratings.title: Prey (2022)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Lean, primal hunt-and-be-hunted thrills that scratched my Predator itch.

simulated_ratings.title: Splinter (2008)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Tight gas-station siege and savage parasite body-horror right in my lane.

simulated_ratings.title: Cloverfield (2008)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Adrenalized, ground-level monster chaos that never lets you breathe.

simulated_ratings.title: The Autopsy of Jane Doe (2016)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Claustrophobic morgue mystery that escalates into occult dread right in my comfort zone.

simulated_ratings.title: The Ruins (2008)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Sun-baked survival and nasty vine-body-horror that gnawed at me.

simulated_ratings.title: Don't Breathe (2016)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Mean, tightly wound home-invasion reversal that had me clenched.

simulated_ratings.title: Sinister (2012)
simulated_ratings.feeling: The Super 8 snuff chill worked, even if the slow-burn supernatural beats wavered.

simulated_ratings.title: The Relic (1997)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Museum-creature siege with chunky practical menace I had fun with.

simulated_ratings.title: From Beyond (1986)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Gooey Lovecraftian mind-and-flesh ripper that scratched my body-horror itch.

simulated_ratings.title: Dog Soldiers (2002)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Soldier-siege werewolf chaos—grimy, punchy, and right up my alley.

simulated_ratings.title: The Fog (1980)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Moody Carpenter ghost-story vibes that creep more than crush.

simulated_ratings.title: The Abyss (1989)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Deep-sea pressure and wonder with enough peril to keep me hooked.

simulated_ratings.title: Leviathan (1989)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Pulp submarine-crew vs. mutation fun with a grungy creature-feature bite.

simulated_ratings.title: Pandorum (2009)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Grim, amnesiac space-hulk nightmare corridors that kept the tension tight.

simulated_ratings.title: Europa Report (2013)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Plausible, chilly space mission that intrigued more than it rattled.

simulated_ratings.title: Gravity (2013)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Bare-knuckle survival-in-space that never let the oxygen—or tension—up.

simulated_ratings.title: Predators (2010)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Serviceable jungle-hunt remix that delivers solid cat-and-mouse heat.

simulated_ratings.title: Dredd (2012)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Brutal, propulsive tower-siege that hits like a sledgehammer.

simulated_ratings.title: Snowpiercer (2013)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Class-war gauntlet with icy momentum and bruising stakes.

simulated_ratings.title: The Terminator (1984)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Relentless techno-noir pursuit machine that still rips.

simulated_ratings.title: Terminator 2: Judgment Day (1991)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Bombastic, high-stakes evolution that keeps the pulse pounding.

simulated_ratings.title: [REC] 2 (2009)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Kinetic, claustrophobic continuation that keeps the infection panic hot.

simulated_ratings.title: Videodrome (1983)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Flesh-tech hallucinations and media rot that burrowed under my skin.

simulated_ratings.title: World War Z (2013)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Globe-trotting outbreak thrills with momentum if not much bite.

simulated_ratings.title: The Grey (2011)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Cheeky animal adventure isn’t my lane at all.

simulated_ratings.title: Coherence (2013)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Dinner-party paranoia spiral with sharp, reality-bending unease.

simulated_ratings.title: The Purge: Anarchy (2014)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Urban-night survival run that’s messy but satisfyingly tense.

simulated_ratings.title: Hell House LLC (2015)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Found-footage haunt that builds real dread inside a cursed attraction.

simulated_ratings.title: Near Dark (1987)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Dusty vampire road-nightmare with a mean, intimate bite.

simulated_ratings.title: Tremors (1990)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Creature-feature siege with crowd-pleasing grit and a wink that mostly works.

simulated_ratings.title: Moon (2009)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Lonely, cerebral sci-fi with identity cracks and a quiet, lingering chill.

simulated_ratings.title: Hellraiser (1987)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Gnarly flesh-craft and occult dread with a puzzle-box pull that pressed all my buttons.

simulated_ratings.title: Hellbound: Hellraiser II (1988)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Bigger, bloodier labyrinth of flesh and doom that keeps the nightmare momentum hot.

simulated_ratings.title: Triangle (2009)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Clever, looping sea-dread that tightens the noose with each pass.

simulated_ratings.title: The Belko Experiment (2016)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Mean, blunt-force office survival that satisfies even if it lacks much nuance.

simulated_ratings.title: Mayhem (2017)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Gory, gleeful chaos that plays, but the jokey tone keeps me at arm’s length.

simulated_ratings.title: The Bay (2012)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Credible found-footage outbreak with nasty parasite beats that gnawed at me.

simulated_ratings.title: V/H/S/2 (2013)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Uneven tape-dread, but the highs deliver manic, claustrophobic terror jolts.

simulated_ratings.title: Host (2020)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Lean, ruthless Zoom séance that ramps hard and never lets up.

simulated_ratings.title: The Brood (1979)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Cold-blooded psychofury and flesh made manifest—clinical, nasty, right up my alley.

simulated_ratings.title: Society (1989)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Goofy class satire that coasts until the gloriously grotesque payoffs hit.

simulated_ratings.title: The Dark and the Wicked (2020)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Bleak, relentless farmhouse decay that seeped under my skin and stayed.

simulated_ratings.title: Apostle (2018)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Grimy cult dread with flashes of gnarly brutality that work even as the pace wobbles.

simulated_ratings.title: Talk to Me (2022)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Locked-door father–son drama that’s fine but too subdued for my tastes.

simulated_ratings.title: His House (2020)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Refugee guilt and haunted-house terror fuse into tight, unsettling dread that landed.

simulated_ratings.title: No One Will Save You (2023)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Silent, relentless alien siege that scratches both my home-invasion and creature-feature itches.

simulated_ratings.title: Sputnik (2020)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Cold War creature-containment with clinical menace and steady dread I dig.

simulated_ratings.title: District 9 (2009)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Grimy alien apartheid with propulsive body-horror stakes that hit hard.

simulated_ratings.title: Edge of Tomorrow (2014)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Relentless, clever loop-war that keeps the pulse pounding and the stakes sharp.

simulated_ratings.title: Riddick (2013)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Back-to-basics monster night-hunt that works, even if it’s a rougher remix.

simulated_ratings.title: Attack the Block (2011)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Street-level creature siege with punchy momentum that kept me grinning and tense.

simulated_ratings.title: Eden Lake (2008)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Mean, grounded survival spiral that left me clenched and seething.

simulated_ratings.title: The Night House (2020)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Campy mad-science shenanigans aren’t my lane, even with the pulpy brain-swap hooks.
